text:
Well, thank you for
being here everyone. You say it's so gracious
of me to come out here.

Thank you for the invitation. But it is also great to escape
Michigan winter for a few days,

so I jumped at the
opportunity to do that. Today I'm going to be presenting
on an intersectional approach

to accessible computing, and
I'll get into what exactly that means.

But first, I want to
lead with this premise that human computer
interaction really

aims to center humans in
computing-- computing related

decisions, and
design, et cetera. But this isn't always the case.

So then I phrased
this question of, what happens when
we do not do this? Our intentions are
that we are doing so

in ways that are
meaningful, that supports communities, and
helps communities, et cetera, but that is not always the case.

So I want to just share
a few examples that have popped up over the last--
I don't know-- five or so years. One is around gender bias.

This is a screenshot from
an article on Amazon, where researchers revealed that
Amazon's hiring tool exhibited

gender bias, where it was
biased against resumes and applications that contained
the word women's, in any case

whether it was a particular
women's university, or organizations that
someone was part of,

it negatively ranked people
with the word women's

in their resume. So they found this
out and they fixed it. We also see instances of bias
based on race and ethnicity.

There's a tweet on the left that
shows how a Black man was tagged

using an image recognition
system solely with terms related to race and ethnicity
instead of other tags

when he had used other
images of white men, which would say things like doctor,
or parents, or handsome.

And then on the right is a
screenshot from a New York Times article showing how popular
smart speakers were essentially

misidentifying words
from Black people more so than white people.

And so this is Black and white-- there are many other
layers in between, but this is really showing how
there's not only gender bias,

but there's race
related bias as well. And then there are
these big implications

for this type of bias
based on race or gender, such as in healthcare or
in mortgage algorithms,

and there are tons of
others examples of this. And this one book that I really
like, if you have not yet

read it, I'd highly
encourage it, it's weapons of math destruction
by Cathy O'Neil, which really

highlights tons of examples
in how bias is exhibited

in systems at a scalable level. And so these examples that
I've just presented primarily
focus on race or gender. But identity is multifaceted.

So this is an image
of Oprah Winfrey, she is not just female
and not just Black

but the intersection
of both of them. And so this screenshot shows
how this image of Oprah

is incorrectly identified
as male with a very fairly

strong confidence metric
here, 76% certain that Oprah Winfrey is male, which is
very wrong, 100% wrong.

And there are similar biases
with other examples of people

with these intersectional
identities, such as Michelle Obama
when she was younger

and she's predicted to be a
young man wearing a black shirt

with fairly high confidence,
both of which are very wrong. And then there is even
confidence levels--

even higher confidence levels
that she is wearing a hairpiece, and that's actually her hair. And so these systems not only
misclassify Oprah and Michelle

Obama but they also
completely fail to acknowledge these different
intersectional identities

of someone is not
just male/female but also can be
female and et cetera.

And so this is what this
term intersectionality really emphasizes, it was made
popular by Kimberle Crenshaw

and it discusses the unique
experiences of Black women, and how they are different from
the experiences of just being

a woman or just being Black. And so I have a description
of intersectionality

from a paper led by Sheena Erete
that describes intersectionality

at this higher
level as emphasizing the importance of understanding,
the combination of one's

identities instead of
a singular identity, particularly with
historically minoritized,

identities that are
discriminated against and don't benefit from
the privilege in ways

that these majority groups do. And then often discuss, I
have some circles on the side

here, often discuss
our identities, like race, and
gender, and ethnicity,

when we think about
intersectionality. But in today's talk,
I'm going to be arguing for extending discussions
about intersectional identities

to disability and older age as
they relate to accessibility

more broadly because that is
my particular research area. I really focus on older adults,
and at least at the moment

blind and low
vision communities, and how they can best be
supported in computing systems

broadly defined. So the central question guiding
today's presentation is,

how can human computer
interaction as a field use an intersectional approach
to designing for disability?

And so I'm going to use two
related studies to basically

answer this first
subquestion of, why an intersectional
approach is important?

And then ends with a
study that demonstrates how an intersectional lens
really affects design.

So first, why is an
intersectional approach important? I'm going to discuss this
in the context of disability

intersecting with older age. So when I discuss
disability and age, I want to highlight
that disability is not

synonymous with aging, but it
is highly correlated with aging.

So these statistics up here are
showing that 15% of the world

has one or more
disabilities, where when you look at those who
are over the age of 60, that number significantly
increases to 46% of people

have more than one disability. And then similarly with
chronic conditions, where one in four adults have
at least two chronic conditions.

And then when you look at
older adults, more than half have three or more conditions. And so chronic conditions.

So this is why I say that
disability and older age, they don't equate to one
another but they are correlated.

Similarly, disability
affects internet access,

it really complicates access to
a lot of computing systems that rely on the internet.

So I have a chart up here that
is enlarged and redesigned,

essentially from a paper
by Dobransky and Hargittai, where they provide
evidence of what they call

this digital disability divide. And so they conducted
a survey with people

who identify as disabled
and those who do not, and they find that 80% of the
respondents without disabilities

use the internet, whereas only
47.8% of those with disabilities

use the internet. And then of those
numbers of those who use the internet
broadly speaking,

those who have broadband
internet access in their homes, 77% were people without
disabilities, and then

So you're seeing that disability
does affect internet access.

But also older age
affects internet access, and these numbers are a
little older at the moment.

But in the most recent
version of this report from Pew Research, they
show that internet use

and broadband internet
access in one's home dropped significantly when
someone is over the age of 75,

and even more
significantly with those who are over the age of 80.

And so both disability and
age affect internet access

when they're studied separately. And so you can only imagine at
the intersection of these two,

the same problem exists. So in the first part of
this, this presentation

I'm going to focus again
on the intersection of these two identities--
disability and older age,

specifically vision loss. So blind and low vision
communities because vision loss

is very prevalent among
the older adult population. And up here I have a statistic
showing describing age

related macular
degeneration, which is one type of health condition
that leads to late life vision

loss. And so one report states
that there were 11 million

older adults in
the United States with age related
macular degeneration.

And this number is
only expected to grow. I think this report said
that it was expected to double within
the next 30 years,

and this was a report from 2016,
which is not that far away now

that we are in 2023. And so you might be
thinking, well, there

are tons of technologies
that can support blind and low vision,
people blind and low

vision older adults in
accessing the internet, and that is correct.

There are assistive technologies
like screen readers, or even screen magnifiers that can
support technology access

with vision loss. But in my prior work with blind
and low vision older adults,

I learned that was a little
bit more complicated than what I was expecting it to be.

So many we interview blind
and low vision older adults and many of them were interested
in engaging online, but learning

to use these assistive
technologies became super overwhelming. They're like I do
not want to learn

how to use a screen reader. This has 100 different
keyboard shortcuts, I'm never going to
remember all of them.

And so it became so overwhelming
that those older adults who were active online
before vision loss

often became inactive after
the onset of vision loss,

experiencing vision
loss or blindness. So yes, there are some
technologies that exist,

but they don't
necessarily solve quote, unquote, these
"issues" of access

a different online communities,
information online, et cetera.

So to support this desire for
accessible online engagement,

I worked with a
group of students to build an interactive
voice response or IVR,

community called xPress. And so if you're less
familiar with this term IVR,

it's essentially
something that people can interact with
through keypad, or voice input, often on
some type of phone device.

You can think of IVR
systems, unfortunately I'm going to lead with
a negative version. These customer
service phone trees

that are so annoying, where
it's like, press one to do this, press two to do that. That's the annoying version. But there is a better
version of that.

So we built this
xPress system kind of mimicking that
in a sense, but it's

more of a blogging
community that's accessible to anyone that has
a phone that can dial a number.

So this doesn't have
to be a smartphone, it could be a landline phone,
it could be a non-smartphone.

And so I just want
to briefly give a bit more detail about this system.

So I did say it was inspired
by these customer service trees but at a higher level, it's
actually more so inspired

by a lot of work
from researchers in the global south who find
that these interactive voice

response communities are super
helpful for those who either don't have internet access or
face some type of challenge

with internet access. And so across a
two-year period, I

had done a series of
formative observations, and interviews, prototype
testing with older adults,

or a particular long-term
care community right outside of Northwestern in Chicago.

And it showed how they
were seeking engagement, they wanted to engage
with others online

but they hated
accessing a computer, like going to this
computer room, figuring out how to turn
on the computer and log in.

And then the password resets
were a whole other story, where you had to reset the
password for one email address,

and then reset the password
to the backup email address, and the backup. So they were like, we don't
want to deal with this at all,

we would much rather interact by
phone, by speaking on a phone. And then we did some interviews
with older adult bloggers,

who were really describing
how meaningful blogging was on a computer.

They were describing
how meaningful it was as a practice in late life. And so that's why we decided to
merge this idea of interacting

by phone with some type
of blogging community as a meaningful
engagement practice.

So we published the findings of
the formative work in T access paper and a [? CHI ?] paper so
you can get more of the details

if you're interested in it. But I just wanted to start by
briefly walking through how

xPress works, because you say
blogging on a landline phone and people are often
very confused by that

and understandably so. So first, when
someone dials in, we

use Twilio, which is essentially
this voice cloud application tool.

And Twilio routes users
to this Python script that then checks a MySQL database.

So essentially pull
the profile information of the number that's
coming in, the person who's

dialing in to authenticate
them to the correct account. So no one needs
to use a password

at all, which is one
of the biggest barriers that we observed
from observations

and in this particular
long-term care community. And so they're authenticated
based on the number that they

dial in from, this script
then reads out loud a main menu using text
to speech and VoiceXML,

and users could do
one of three things. So it's not this long
complicated customer service

phone tree. They could do one
of three things. If they press one,
they can listen to others posts and
comments, if they press two,

they can listen to their
own posts and comments, and then if they press three,
they can record a new post.

And so they're
interacting here-- and I put up here the
image of the keypad-- they're interacting here
through keypad input

as opposed to voice input. Because of research which
shows if someone is completely

unfamiliar with the
system, you tell them to use voice input to navigate.

They're not going
to be sure of how to navigate through that
system, so we use keypad input to give them very specific
options of what they could do.

So they interact
through keypad input. If they want to listen to
others post or their own post,

they then hear a recording
of that exact post and also comments, they
hear the exact recording.

And then if they want
to create a post, they record the message
by speaking directly

into the phone receiver. They press a digit to
signal the end of the post.

And then they could either
hear that post replayed and decide that they want
to rerecord or hear the post

replayed and decide,
now, I'm good with this, publish
this to the system. So after they publish
the post, the address

of the audio recording is
then stored in the database to be retrieved
anytime if someone wants to listen to a post,
and the same with the comment.

And then it's also made
available to other xPress users. And so the benefits of this
are that older adults do not

need to purchase an
additional device or learn how to use a completely
unfamiliar system because it was

very similar to not only
customer service phone trees, but also voice mail, which I
personally no longer check,

but someone still
checks their voice mail. And so they're really familiar
with this type of metaphor.

And so overall,
xPress is enabling us to study new forms
of online interaction

amongst blind and low
vision older adults. So before I move to what we did
with xPress, how people use it,

are there any questions
about how it works? Anything I can clarify? Yes. Are there any things
about security?

So I'm very familiar with the-- oh, they have to give secret
word, birth date, something

to ensure that the person
who's calling is actually me and not someone
who has my phone. That's a good question.

We did not implement
any security mechanisms here other than the
fact that we knew--

we asked them what phone number
they would be dialing in from, and Twilio essentially can
take can pull the phone

number of the
person who's dialing and we use that to authenticate
them to the account. But there are lots
of questions, there

are options to then give
people a particular pin number. They choose a two digit
number or a four digit number

when they dial in to
double authenticate them into that account. But we didn't do
that in this case.

Yeah, good question. Yes. How is the user able to navigate
through all the information?

Like listening to
other people's posts, how are they able to navigate?

Yeah, that's a good question. I didn't say all of
these other numbers did. So the high level navigation
of listen to others,

listen to own and
create a new post, and then when they
go into listening, let's just say listening
to others post,

there are ways that they can
skip around in the system. So I think four was
replay the post,

six was skip to the next post. And so that way they could kind
of traverse through the system.

The posts were also
similar to a blog or presented reverse
chronologically.

So the newest one was
always presented first and then they could go
backwards from there.

Did that answer your question? [INAUDIBLE] if they
want to save a blog post

becasue I won't go back,
is there a way to do that? Yeah. So that's a great question. There was no saving
in this version,

we were trying to strip blogging
down to its basic fundamentals. We initially had
in some other like,

seven, eight, and nine, where
some other numbers as well, zero was always back
to the main menu. But then when we presented
it to older adults,

it was very confusing. So we just removed those
additional features. And there were
instances where we--

for comments we would use
double numbers to represent the same thing that you could
do with posts, like 44 replay

a comment, 66 would
replay the post or skip to the next comment
very similar to a post.

And we found that was OK. But once we started to reuse
numbers for other things,

that's when things
got confusing. Because there is a
little bit of more of a cognitive
burden of listening

to content in an online
community than looking at it visually. So that's why we removed a
lot of the additional features

that you might find on a
traditional blogging platform. And I feel like there
was another question.

Yes. When users try to create a new
post, how easy is that process?

Because I suspect that the
recording from audio to text

may not work very well,
as there are still technology limitations.

What's the quality
of that process? And how easy it is for
users to create new posts, make edits, et cetera?

So that's a great
question because that's one of the reasons why we
use the exact recording

to play back the person's post. So if they want to
create a new post, they record directly
into the phone receiver,

and then that's
the exact recording that is then played
anytime someone else wants to listen to that post. It's never converted into text.

So part of that was the
speech to text recognition

wasn't the greatest at the
time and still not always the greatest. But also people really liked
when we prototyped this system,

people really liked the emotion
that they can hear from someone else's voice through a
direct recording as opposed

to having more of
the synthetic speech, like they could get to
know whether someone was being sarcastic or not.

And so that's why we kept
just the straight recording. Did that answer your question?
OK. Great. All great questions.

So we then deployed xPress
to blind and low vision older adults, and we wanted
to understand how they used.

This voice community
what afforded meaning in voice communities? What was meaningful?

And then what benefits the voice
communities like xPress provide?

So we worked with several
students, and two of which are on pictured here-- Sam Ankenbauer
and Pooja Upadhyay

to lead two field
deployments with xPress. So the first is more
of a pilot, that

was with seven blind and
low vision older adults, they all had
acquired vision loss,

and this was over
a 10-week period. And then the second
was a much longer study

that was funded through the
retirement research foundation, and it was a one-year
field deployment

with 43 blind and low vision
older adults have about half of which were assigned to
this intervention condition,

where they used
xPress, and about half were assigned to this
control group, where they did not use xPress at all.

And so for both groups,
those who use xPress and those who didn't in
this one-year deployment,

we did collect a few things
at the one-month, six-month, and 12-month period,
specifically we

measured loneliness
and social support.

So while not significant these
measures around loneliness

and social support, and I'll
explain a little bit about why in a few. We did notice some trends.

So one is that loneliness
decreased for everyone in the study, but this was
more pronounced for those

who used xPress for those
who were in the intervention condition. Meaning that this difference
between one-month-- the first

month and the 12-month was
the larger for those who used xPress.

And then we saw similar
trends with social support, where you might have the kind of
flip things in your mind here.

A lower social support
score here actually means higher social support.

So overall, people felt like
they had more social support

if they used xPress compared
to those who did not. And so we note that
these are trends

and not statistically
significant because we did this
study in the pandemic,

in the height of
things, so everyone was less lonely at the end and
everyone felt more socially

supported at the end. So people had different
social distancing requirements depending on what state
they were dialing in from,

so it was a little bit messy to
see any statistical significance

changes there. But we did see some
improvements some trends, we want to do this
at a larger scale,

we were seeing some
more significant trends in the first six months,
especially related to loneliness. And so we're kind
of thinking, well,

maybe these types
of voice communities are better for people when
they're more extremely isolated because
this was May of 2020

is when the first
person was enrolled. And so they were enrolled
between May and November of 2020

and then a year from
that they ended. So we're thinking when people
are more extremely isolated, maybe these voice communities
could provide support.

But beyond the survey data,
what was most interesting were these qualitative
findings related to disability.

So first, blogging
by phone using xPress provided opportunities
for meeting new people

and connecting on
a deeper level, which participants described
was difficult to do elsewhere.

So there's a quote from
one participant who said, "If I'm walking on the
street, you would say, 'hi, can I help you?'

That was all you would do. You wouldn't say,
'hi, how are you? What can I do for you?'" And so for him, there's
always this stigma

of having a quote, unquote,
"visible disability" because you use a white cane to
navigate around barriers

in his environment,
and so people always assumed that he needed help when
he was out navigating somewhere

instead of just trying
to start a conversation without that assistance
component within it.

So by using the phone to
blog, he can more easily talk to people about
different topics,

and participants really
valued this type of depth of conversation and connection.

Participants also described
how blogging by phone was a safe space to
work through disability.

So they talked about topics
like finding accessible voting booths, or many really rallied
around this one person who

described recently having
some vision changes and no longer being able to
drive due to his vision loss.

So because of the amount that
this was a seven person pilot

and people really valued
the topics and the system, I said, OK, well,
what if we were to increase the number of people
who were using this system?

We had already
done a study where I'd interviewed older
adults who were blogging, cited older adult bloggers,
who were already very involved

with blogging and so I said. I asked the participants in this
study, the blind and low vision older adults.

You all seem to be wanting some
more content in this system, do you mind if I invite
cited older adult bloggers?

And initially
everyone was on board with that, all seven
participants said that would be great to
hear from other people,

they're also older, like
maybe we can learn from them, or maybe they can learn
from us, et cetera.

But after the blind and low
vision older adults actually heard the content from
the sighted older adults,

they definitely
changed their minds. And so one person said,
"I can get that anywhere. I don't need to have
a certain site that's

just for the visually
challenged to have everybody else in there." So they actually did not--

after hearing the
content, they did not want sighted older adults
to be on this system

at all, because they hear the
experiences they call them the majority, they hear the
experiences of the majority

daily and they
really valued this being a system that was
specifically for blind and low

vision older adults. Now they said, well,
maybe they could listen, but they shouldn't be
able to contribute. Maybe they could listen
and learn about disability,

but we don't want to hear
what they have to say, particularly I remember
some of these posts

where some of the
sighted bloggers were talking about how
beautiful of a day it was and how the colors
were shining and it's

like that's not what they want
to hear in this community. So these data points helped us
to understand the boundaries

on community participation,
and also highlighted the importance of
designing for intersecting

disability experiences. So what I mean by
that, it's more

so like just because
someone is an older adult, it doesn't mean that
their experiences are

the same as a blind and
low vision older adult. And similarly if someone
is younger and has

some type of vision
impairment, that does not mean that
their experiences are going to be the same of someone
who is older with a vision

impairment. So these concepts around
intersectionality, intersectional critical
theory have really typically

been discussed in the context of
race, class, or gender studies,

describing again,
this importance of the intersection of two
or more oppressed groups.

And here, I'm using
this intersectional lens to really discuss the
intersection of age

and disability. So kind of returning back to
this original question of,

why it is important to use
an intersectional approach?

But really here we're
seeing that it can really impact the value that someone
places on a community,

or participants really
valued the community when it was only
blind and low vision older adults and they
didn't want to really use it

once sighted people started
to come and quote, unquote, "infiltrate" the system.

So can impact the value that
someone places on community. Now the last part
of this talk, I

wanted to briefly
use some recent work to discuss how an intersectional
approach might affect design.

But before this, it's kind
of a separate each topic although it's connected
by intersectionality. Were there any questions on
the previous study with xPress?

Yes. When are there any requirements
for users of [INAUDIBLE]

making sure it's all organic? It's organic. We did after their initial
pre-interview we said,

hey, try it out. Let us know if you
have any questions. We recommend trying to listen to
one post, and create one post,

and comment on one post. But after that, we didn't
have any requirements for use

because we didn't want to
force them to use something.

You have a question? Yeah, what kind of phones? Are they using
smartphones or just the old-school physical phones?

Yeah. Most were using landline phones. Because we did do
some in-home visits

during the first interview--
at least for the pilot study, we know that most were
using landline phones.

For the second study,
that was in May of 2020, we weren't exactly sure what
types of phones they were using.

But from the pilot, we did
learn that they preferred landline phones
with raised buttons

so that they could
tell which button they were pressing instead of
having to use a screen reader and swipe through to figure out
what button they were pressing

on a touch screen. So yeah, most were using
landline at least in the pilot. And I imagine if
it wasn't landline

for the full deployment, a lot
were also using cell phones

with raised buttons. So more like feature
or non-smart phones.

Is it possible for users to-- I guess like form groups within
while using the application

whereas just-- whether it's a
specific topic, they're able to all focus in versus
the inflow of topics?

Right. So instead of presenting
the topics or the post reverse chronological order but
they find different topics--

not in this version
though, and so that was something that people
said that they wanted. And we were trying
to figure out a way

to do this without reusing
too many buttons on the phone

or ways to do that
through speech might be another way moving forward. And it did seem people were
forming their own mini groups,

where they would always go back
and listen to the same people's posts and comment on
the same people's posts,

but not in a formal. It wasn't formally
structured that way.

Yes. I'm curious if you got the
common online community dynamics of--

I don't know-- influencers,
lurkers that kind of stuff? Or did it in any way
transmogrified by the context

here? We did-- and I'm wondering if I
have a backup slide-- but yes.

We did see that there were--
especially in the one-year long deployment, we were able to
see those patterns a bit more,

where there were
people who were-- we called them top
listeners, and there

were people who
were top posters, and often they
did not intersect.

Like there was a whole group
of people who was listening, and then sometimes
called lurking,

and then there was a whole
group of people who were always contributing the content. So we did see kind of those
similar contribution patterns

there. And our next step is to--
actually I'm supposed to be working on this in
the next month or so--

writing a paper where we provide
more detail about the narratives

of how listeners and
posters use the system, because they use it
in different ways.

Often it mimics
their interactions on screen-based online
communities, where people would

say like, oh, I'm a
lurker on Facebook and I also am a lurker here. They didn't actually
use those words. But essentially it did
mimic their behavior
in other communities.

So next, again, we're
going to get into, how can HCI I use an
intersectional approach

to design, specifically how
my intersectionality affect design itself?

And so this is a study that
focuses on the intersection of disability and ethnicity.

This work was led by PhD
student Rahaf Alharbi at University of Michigan as
part of a team with Sarita

Schoenebeck. And this next project
focuses on visual description

or visual assistance services,
like Microsoft's SeeingAI,

which is very helpful for
describing a visual content to blind and low vision people.

So we have a few examples
here of this particular app is useful for describing short
text, details about people,

about products or cans,
about currency, what are these different
bills, et cetera.

But it's also helpful in
